predicate.note: Frames file for 'file' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus

roleset.name: paperwork

example.name: active
example.text: [David Dinkins]-1 failed *trace*-1 to file his income taxes.

example.name: lawsuit
example.text: University Patents filed a suit in federal court in Philadelphia against Albert M. Kligman.

roleset.note: Sometimes the against phrase is included in the suit phrase. You'll therefore need to delve deeper into the syntax to divide the two args.

example.name: passivized
example.text: Documents-1 filed *trace*-1 with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the pending spinoff...
example.arg: with the Securities and Exchange Commission

roleset.note: This happens a lot, with something that looks (syntactically) like an argument of "file" but is actually a modifier of the head NP--really --> --this is "documents on the pending spinoff were filed with the SEC" --> --but the syntax has been bollixed. Use ArgM for all these.

example.name: with purpose
example.text: A group of investors filed with federal antitrust regulators for clearance to buy more than 50% of the stock of Rally's Inc.
example.arg: for clearance to buy more than 50% of the stock of Rally's Inc

roleset.name: seek, claim, call for

example.text: One or more airlines have filed for protection from creditors.

roleset.note: The difference between this and the Arg-4 "purpose" is that in this case the paperwork cannot be mentioned. With the roleset (file.01) above, the paperwork need not be mentioned, but can be. Other arguments (filed-with, filed-against) will probably be mentioned.

example.name: gorgeous british slang
example.text: A stream of tire-kickers and lookee-loos had filed through since.
example.arg: A stream of tire-kickers and lookee-loos
